subject: Business
title: OKRs: Objectives and Key Results
description: A quick, practical guide to OKRs: Objectives and Key Results.

hook.text: Andy Grove at Intel invented OKRs. John Doerr brought them to Google. They became Silicon Valley's operating system.

buildup.text: An objective says where you want to go. Key results are the measurable milestones that prove you got there.

discovery.text: Good OKRs are ambitious but measurable. 'Improve customer satisfaction' is vague. 'Raise NPS from 30 to 50' is an OKR.

twist.text: If you hit 100% of your OKRs, they weren't ambitious enough. Google aims for 60-70% achievement.

climax.text: OKRs align entire organizations. Every team's key results connect to the company's top objectives.

punchline.text: Tell everyone where you're going. Then measure every step.

quiz.question: Why does Google aim for 60-70% OKR achievement, not 100%?
options: 100% means the goals weren't ambitious enough
They expect employees to fail regularly
OKRs are optional targets, not requirements
